'''Gardner Rea''' (1894 – December 29, 1966) was an [[United States|American]] [[cartoonist]], and one of the original contributing artists to ''[[The New Yorker]]''.<ref name="obit">{{cite web |url = http://brookhavensouthhaven.org/history/Rea/GardnerReaObituary.htm |title = Gardner Rea Obituary |date = December 29, 1966 |publisher = Brookhaven/South Haven.org |accessdate = November 7, 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091124222442/http://brookhavensouthhaven.org/history/Rea/GardnerReaObituary.htm |archivedate = November 24, 2009 |df = }}</ref> Of Rea, one commentator has written: “He was bawdy without being obscene, absurd without being obscure. His captioned and uncaptioned gags were pithy and true.”<ref name="heller">{{cite web|url=http://www.printmag.com/Article/Rah-Rah-Rah-for-Gardner-Rea|title= Rah Rah Rah for Gardner Rea|author=Steven Heller|date= September 24, 2009|publisher= ''Print'' magazine|accessdate=November 7, 2009}}</ref>
A native of [[Ironton, Ohio]], Rea was born into an artistic family and planned to become a painter. When he was fifteen years old, he sold a gag cartoon to ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine.<ref name="obit"/>
He attended [[East High School (Columbus, Ohio)|East High School]] in [[Columbus, Ohio]] and [[Ohio State University]], where he met and befriended [[James Thurber]].<ref name="obit"/> Rea played tennis in college and was the editor of the humor magazine, the ''Sundial'',<ref name="obit"/> which he had helped to found.<ref>Judith Yaross Lee, ''Defining New Yorker humor: Studies in popular culture'' (Univ. Press of Mississippi, 2000), 377n.</ref>
From 1914, he worked as a freelance writer and artist in [[Manhattan]], and contributed to ''Life'' and ''[[Judge (magazine)|Judge]]'' magazines.<ref name="obit"/> During [[World War I]], he served in the [[Chemical Warfare Service]].<ref name="obit"/>
He began contributing not only drawings and covers but also gags to ''The New Yorker'' after it was founded in 1925.<ref name="obit"/> Artists such as [[Charles Addams]] and [[Helen Hokinson]] drew cartoons based on gags written by Rea.<ref name="obit"/>
Gardner Rea in the mid 1930s was a regular contributor to the Communist Party's literary magazine "New Masses," with work appearing in nearly every weekly issues in the years 1936 and 1937.<ref>See: [https://www.marxists.org/history/usa/pubs/new-masses/ New Masses archive], www.marxists.org/</ref>
